refnamediv.refpurpose: arrays of arbitrary elements which grow automatically as elements are added.

refsynopsisdiv.title: Synopsis

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Arrays are similar to standard C arrays, except that they grow automatically as elements are added.
Array elements can be of any size (though all elements of one array are the same size), and the array can be automatically cleared to '0's and zero-terminated.
To create a new array use g_array_new().
To add elements to an array, use g_array_append_val(), g_array_append_vals(), g_array_prepend_val(), and g_array_prepend_vals().
To access an element of an array, use g_array_index().
To set the size of an array, use g_array_set_size().
To free an array, use g_array_free().

refsect2.title: GArray
refsect2.para: Contains the public fields of an Array.

refsect2.title: g_array_new ()
refsect2.para: Creates a new GArray.

listitem.simpara: TRUE if the array should have an extra element at the end which is set to 0.
TRUE if GArray elements should be automatically cleared to 0 when they are allocated.
the size of each element in bytes.

refsect2.title: g_array_sized_new ()
refsect2.programlisting: GArray* g_array_sized_new (gboolean zero_terminated, gboolean clear_, guint element_size, guint reserved_size);
refsect2.para: Creates a new GArray with reserved_size elements preallocated. This avoids frequent reallocation, if you are going to add many elements to the array. Note however that the size of the array is still 0.

listitem.simpara: TRUE if the array should have an extra element at the end with all bits cleared.
TRUE if all bits in the array should be cleared to 0 on allocation.
size of each element in the array.

refsect2.title: g_array_append_val()
refsect2.para: Adds the value on to the end of the array. The array will grow in size automatically if necessary.

note.para: g_array_append_val() is a macro which uses a reference to the value parameter v. This means that you cannot use it with literal values such as "27". You must use variables.

listitem.simpara: the value to append to the GArray.

refsect2.title: g_array_append_vals ()
refsect2.para: Adds len elements onto the end of the array.

listitem.simpara: a pointer to the elements to append to the end of the array.
the number of elements to append.

refsect2.title: g_array_prepend_val()
refsect2.para: Adds the value on to the start of the array. The array will grow in size automatically if necessary.
This operation is slower than g_array_append_val() since the existing elements in the array have to be moved to make space for the new element.

note.para: g_array_prepend_val() is a macro which uses a reference to the value parameter v. This means that you cannot use it with literal values such as "27". You must use variables.

listitem.simpara: the value to prepend to the GArray.

refsect2.title: g_array_prepend_vals ()
refsect2.para: Adds len elements onto the start of the array.
This operation is slower than g_array_append_vals() since the existing elements in the array have to be moved to make space for the new elements.

listitem.simpara: a pointer to the elements to prepend to the start of the array.
the number of elements to prepend.

refsect2.title: g_array_insert_val()
refsect2.para: Inserts an element into an array at the given index.

note.para: g_array_insert_val() is a macro which uses a reference to the value parameter v. This means that you cannot use it with literal values such as "27". You must use variables.

listitem.simpara: the index to place the element at.
the value to insert into the array.

refsect2.title: g_array_insert_vals ()
refsect2.programlisting: GArray* g_array_insert_vals (GArray *array, guint index_, gconstpointer data, guint len);
refsect2.para: Inserts len elements into a GArray at the given index.

listitem.simpara: the index to place the elements at.
a pointer to the elements to insert.
the number of elements to insert.

refsect2.title: g_array_remove_index ()
refsect2.para: Removes the element at the given index from a GArray. The following elements are moved down one place.

listitem.simpara: the index of the element to remove.

refsect2.title: g_array_remove_index_fast ()
refsect2.para: Removes the element at the given index from a GArray. The last element in the array is used to fill in the space, so this function does not preserve the order of the GArray. But it is faster than g_array_remove_index().

listitem.simpara: the index of the element to remove.

refsect2.title: g_array_remove_range ()
refsect2.para: Removes the given number of elements starting at the given index from a GArray. The following elements are moved to close the gap.

listitem.simpara: the index of the first element to remove.
the number of elements to remove.

refsect2.para: Since 2.4

refsect2.title: g_array_sort ()
refsect2.para: If two array elements compare equal, their order in the sorted array is undefined.

refsect2.title: g_array_sort_with_data ()
refsect2.para: Like g_array_sort(), but the comparison function receives an extra user data argument.

refsect2.title: g_array_index()

listitem.simpara: the index of the element to return.
the element of the GArray at the index given by i.

refsect2.title: g_array_set_size ()
refsect2.para: Sets the size of the array, expanding it if necessary. If the array was created with clear_ set to TRUE, the new elements are set to 0.

listitem.simpara: the new size of the GArray.

refsect2.title: g_array_free ()
refsect2.para: Frees the memory allocated for the GArray. If free_segment is TRUE it frees the memory block holding the elements as well. Pass FALSE if you want to free the GArray wrapper but preserve the underlying array for use elsewhere.

note.para: If array elements contain dynamically-allocated memory, they should be freed first.

listitem.simpara: if TRUE the actual element data is freed as well.
the element data if free_segment is FALSE, otherwise NULL
